intro: Aira caryophyllea subsp. patulipes, commonly known as the purple false oat, is a perennial grass species native to the western United States. It is characterized by its tall, slender stems and clusters of small, violet-colored flowers that bloom in late summer. The plant has narrow, grass-like leaves and produces seeds in spikelets, typical of the Poaceae family. It thrives in dry, open habitats such as grasslands and rocky slopes. Its botanical features make it an important component of native plant communities in arid regions.
